Defintion: Structures extending more or less perpendicularly from the shore into a body of water, which are designed to direct and confine the current or tide, to protect a harbor, or to prevent shoaling of a navigable inlet by littoral materials.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform Type (Level 2)
Defintion: A small jetty extending perpendicular from the shore designed to reduce beach erosion. Groins provide hard substrate in what is often an area dominated by unconsolidated sediments.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: The shoreline that is created along the channel formed by jetties.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: An artificially reinforced section of the shoreline (or the structure itself). These can be composed of piles of natural material (such as rip-rap), or they may resemble walls of timbers or other substance. They may have many purposes but generally are not intended to prevent flooding of lower areas.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: An area through which one or more cables have been placed in (or on) the substrate. These areas can be navigation hazards, so they are commonly noted on nautical charts. Scarring, debris, and other features associated with cable installation or maintenance may be present.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Structures that serve as linear conduits for electricity or as supporting lines for other in-water or above-water infrastructure.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: (a) Man-made channels produced to facilitate navigation between water bodies. (b) Generally linear, dredged, closed-ended ditches that have been dug between housing units along the coast.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: An obstruction across a flow that produces a lake, pond, or other widening.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A landing place for vessels normally oriented perpendicular to the shore with a flat surface for off-loading materials. Docks may be fixed in position through anchors or piles, or be supported by pilings or other structures.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: A roughly linear, deep area within an existing water body formed by a dredging operation for navigation purposes (after Wells et al. 1994).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: A subaqueous area that is substantially shallower than the surrounding area, which resulted from the deposition of materials from dredging and dumping.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform Type (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: A subaqueous area that is substantially shallower than the surrounding area, which resulted from the deposition of materials from dredging and dumping.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform Type (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: A subaerial mound or ridge (which permanently stands above the water) composed of randomly mixed sediments deposited during dredging and dumping.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: An area of the seafloor impacted by dredging activities. In this instance, the term is meant to apply to secondary scarring, smothering, or destruction of epibenthic and near-surface infaunal communities by dredging activity (rather than the direct removal of material by dredging which would be characterized under the Dredged Channel or other geoforms).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Large structures built to house workers and machinery needed to drill wells in the ocean bed in order to extract oil or other natural resources. They may be attached to the ocean floor, consist of an artificial island, or be floating; rigs often provide important structure and attachment points for marine animals.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A topographically low area into which unconsolidated material has been placed in order to raise the ground level as part of development or expansion of coastal infrastructure.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform Type (Level 2)
Defintion: A fill area where some form of solid waste is being used as the fill material.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: These are mostly enclosed basins, usually along the shore used to trap fish. During high tide they are open to the sea but as the tide recedes they become cut off to allow capture of the trapped fish. These features may be very old and have strong cultural and archaeological significance.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: A small bay or a sheltered part of a sea, lake, or other large body of water. A harbor is usually well protected (either naturally or artificially) against high waves and strong currents and serves as a safe anchorage for ships and where port facilities are present. Many smaller anthropogenic geoforms may be encountered within a harbor.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A chamber designed to lift vessels- from one water body to another- by adjusting the level of water in the chamber.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: This consists of nets, floats, weights and cabling associated with fishing activities, usually at a commercial level. This type of debris forms a serious hazard for marine life and can persist in the environment for long periods.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A series of docks, walkways, slips, and support infrastructure (such as cables and small pipelines) for in-water storage of yachts and boats. Marinas commonly include one or more boat ramps, which consist of a sloping driveway for launching small, trailered vessels.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: These are anchorages with many small, fixed buoys in place for securing yachts and other vessels.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Straight, narrow channels that were dug to drain the upper reaches of salt marshes in order to control the populations of mosquitoes that breed there. However, draining the standing water also impacts populations of mosquito-eating fish that live in those waters (http://www.edc.uri.edu/restoration/html/intro/salt.htm).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Outfalls are pipelines or tunnels that discharge municipal or industrial wastewater, storm water, combined sewer overflows, cooling water, or brine effluents to a receiving water body. Intakes are pipes designed (and placed) to draw lake or seawater into a man-made pond or other facility.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A structure formed by piles that are long, slender columns- usually made of timber, steel, or reinforced concrete (see Figure 6.10).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: A corridor through which one or more pipelines have been placed.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: An accumulation of rock or boulders placed along a waterway or shoreline to reduce erosion.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: A series of shallow ponds separated by berms or levels, designed to produce salt from marine water or other brines through the process of evapotranspiration. The ponds are periodically drained to harvest salts. These can support various microalgal communities while water is present.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Usually enclosed areas just landward of the shoreline with a permanent-to-intermittent flooding regime of saline-to-hypersaline waters.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1)
Defintion: A man-made wall or embankment of stone, reinforced concrete, or other material along a shore that was built to prevent wave erosion. These are similar to jetties, but seawalls are more commonly oriented along the water's edge (instead of perpendicular to the shore).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Structures that consist of long booms deployed at the surface or turbines placed on the seafloor or other structures. Some portions of these structures may form attachment surfaces for sessile fauna.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 1 or Level 2)
Defintion: Aggregations of submerged, floating or suspended trash. These may be loose and mobile as when floating at the water's surface or consolidated by sediment on the bottom or along shore. Trash aggregations may be the result of local storm or seismic events such as floods or tsunamis. Trash aggregations can also form over long periods due to the action of large gyres and currents as in the mid-Pacific Ocean.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: A structure on the shore of a harbor where ships may dock to load and unload cargo or passengers. A wharf is usually a fixed platform, often on pilings. Smaller and more modern wharves are sometimes built on flotation devices (pontoons) to keep them at the same level as the ship- even during changing tides. Wharves form attachment surfaces for shellfish and sessile epifauna, and they are common aggregation points for fish. Also, wharves are often locations where contaminants are introduced into the environment (through spills or waste disposal).

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Structures deployed in the marine environment in order to produce energy from the wind. These structures often consist of piling, cabling supports, and associated anchoring devices.

Unit Type: CMECS Geoform Subcomponent: Anthropogenic Geoform (Level 2)
Defintion: Any of a variety of man-made structures (such as sunken ships or collapsed drilling rigs) that have fallen to the seafloor. They may be either completely or partially submerged. Wrecks often provide valuable habitat for attaching organisms or fish, but they may also leach contaminants into the environment.
